title: 112_s576
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fitness Integrated with Teaching Kids Act" or the "FIT Kids Act". Congress finds that childhood obesity is at epidemic levels in the United States, costing the economy over $117 billion annually. The prevalence of overweight children and adolescents has significantly increased over the years, with more than 9 million children considered overweight. If children do not become more active and healthy, a third of all children born in 2000 or later will suffer from obesity. A third of children born in 2000 or later will suffer from diabetes in their lifetime. Sedentary lifestyles in childhood contribute to 23% of US deaths from chronic diseases. Overweight adolescents have a high chance of becoming overweight adults, increasing their risk for chronic diseases. Children who are obese or have high cholesterol show plaque build-up in neck arteries similar to middle-aged adults. Decline in physical activity has led to a childhood obesity epidemic. Physical Activity Guidelines recommend 60 minutes of activity daily for children. In a 2005 report, increasing physical activity was highlighted as crucial in programs targeting childhood obesity. Physical education programs in schools have decreased over the past 2 decades. National standards recommend 150 minutes per week in elementary school and 225 minutes per week in middle and high school. However, only a small percentage of schools provide daily physical education, and some schools do not require students to take it. Research shows that a significant percentage of schools do not mandate physical education, leading to low participation rates in organized physical activities among children. Regular physical activity is linked to better health outcomes and academic performance. The majority of adults support the idea of daily physical education in schools. SEC. 3. REPORT CARDS. Section 1111(h) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include requirements for the amount of time students spend in physical education, based on national standards of 150 minutes per week for elementary school students and 225 minutes per week for middle and secondary school students. The curr_chunk discusses the percentage of schools in the State with a required physical education curriculum adhering to national guidelines, the percentage of licensed physical education teachers, and the percentage of schools with a School Health Council including parents. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of a School Health Council with various members to promote a healthy school environment and the requirement for physical education teachers to be State certified. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for physical education teachers to be State certified and the amount of indoor and outdoor facilities used for physical education and activity. The curr_chunk discusses the percentage of elementary and secondary school physical education teachers who are State certified and the number of meetings of a School Health Council during the school year. SEC. 4. PROMOTING PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND ACTIVITY IN SCHOOL PROGRAMS. Elementary and Secondary School Counseling Programs and Smaller Learning Communities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 are amended to include considerations for students' emotional and physical well-being, regular physical activity, and access to nutritious food. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers program is amended to include nutrition education programs and structured physical activity programs. This amendment aims to promote student well-being through access to nutritious food and physical activity. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers program is amended to include programs that support a healthy, active lifestyle, coordinated with physical education and health education programs offered during the school day. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to involve and train parents in encouraging a healthy and active lifestyle, including increased physical activity and nutritional eating habits at home and school. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to involve parents in promoting healthy, active lifestyles for children at home and school, including physical activity and nutrition. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to involve parents in promoting healthy, active lifestyles for children at home and school, including providing healthy meals, encouraging physical education, and coordinating activities with parents and teachers to ensure nutritious meals. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to involve parents in promoting healthy, active lifestyles for children at home and school, including providing nutritious meals and opportunities for physical education and activity. SEC. 5. PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS AND PRINCIPALS. State Applications: Amends Section 2112(b) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to include provisions for professional development in physical education and health education for teachers. State Use of Funds: Amends Section 2113(c)(6) to specify support for physical education teachers. Amends Section 2122(b)(9) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to improve student health and physical activity rates. Amends Section 2123(a)(3) to support physical education and health education teachers. The text chunk amends Section 2122(b)(9) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act by adding effective strategies for improving healthy habits and physical activity rates of students to enhance learning. It also amends Section 2123(a)(3) to provide evidence-based training for physical and health education teachers to improve student learning abilities. The text chunk emphasizes the importance of effective strategies for improving healthy habits and physical activity rates of students to enhance learning. SEC. 6. NATIONAL RESEARCH COUNCIL STUDY. The Secretary of Education will contract the National Research Council to examine ways to incorporate physical activity in educational settings, study the impact of physical activity on students' learning, and provide recommendations for measuring student progress. The National Research Council will examine ways to measure students' progress in improving health and well-being, including nutrition, physical activity, cognitive development, fitness, and obesity reduction. They will also assess progress in increasing physical activity at the school level.
